I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the seventh meeting of the Experts Group on Power Interconnection and Trade (EGP) 
in May 2002, the countries of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS)1 endorsed the findings and 
recommendations of the study for the regional indicative master plan on power interconnection 
and requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for project preparatory technical assistance 
(TA) to prepare a feasibility study for the identified power transmission interconnection between 
the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) and Viet Nam. Following a three-country 
consultation meeting during 16–17 June 2003 in Manila at ADB headquarters, an ADB Fact-
Finding Mission visited Lao PDR, Thailand, and Viet Nam in July/August 2003 and reached an 
understanding with each government on the goals, purpose, scope, outline terms of reference, 
and implementation arrangements for the TA. The TA has been included in ADB’s 2002 GMS 
Subregional Cooperation Strategy and Program Summary and ADB’s 2003 Viet Nam Country 
Strategy and Program Update.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  ADB has played a lead role in GMS cooperation in the electric power sector as part of 
the program for economic cooperation in the GMS that ADB initiated in 1992. The Subregional 
Electric Power Forum (EPF) and EGP meetings under the GMS activities have been held with 
ADB’s assistance to enhance subregional cooperation in the electric power sector. The main 
objectives of the EPF are to (i) promote opportunities for extended economic cooperation in the 
electric power sector; (ii) facilitate implementation of priority subregional power projects; and (iii) 
address technical, economic, financial, and institutional issues relevant to subregional power 
sector development. The EGP was created in June 1998 to discuss detailed work programs and 
recommend its findings to the EPF to (i) promote development of a subregional transmission 
network, and (ii) facilitate the expansion of cross-border power trade. 
 
3.  Subregional  electricity  trade  based  on  interconnected  electric  power networks will 
provide significant economic and environmental benefits for individual countries and the entire 
subregion. Such trade will enable members to (i) reduce national investments in the power 
reserves maintained to meet peak demand; (ii) provide a more reliable supply of electricity, 
including power supply from an interconnected network in case of power failure; (iii) reduce 
operational costs; (iv) reduce greenhouse gas emissions and other pollutants; and (v) increase 
consumers’  access  to  the  cheapest  and  most  environment-friendly  sustainable  source  of 
electricity in the subregion. 
 
4.  To provide the policy framework for promoting opportunities for extended economic 
cooperation  on  regional  power  trade  and  facilitating  the  implementation  of  priority  power 
projects in the GMS, the Policy Statement on Regional Power Trade in the GMS was endorsed 
in January 2000 by all members. In addition, the Inter-Governmental Agreement on Regional 
Power Trade in the GMS (IGA) was signed by all six GMS members at the first GMS summit 
meeting on 3 November 2002. The IGA is the first outcome of the highest commitment by all 
members to promote regional power trade and toward a competitive electricity market. Through 
the IGA, all members can (i) coordinate and cooperate in planning and operating their systems 
to minimize costs while maintaining satisfactory reliability, (ii) fully recover their costs and share

5.  Besides the policy framework for promoting regional power trade, the regional indicative 
master plan on power interconnection in the GMS3 was developed starting in October 2000 with 
ADB’s assistance to (i) identify necessary physical power interconnections in the subregion up 
to  2020;  and  (ii)  harmonize  transmission  planning,  design,  and  operational  practices.  All 
members endorsed the indicative master plan in May 2002 at the seventh meeting of the EGP. 
 
6.  In accordance with the IGA, the guidelines for the establishment of the regional power 
trade coordination committee were discussed and adopted at the eighth EGP meeting on 
10 October 2002. The guidelines specified the objectives, function, representation, coordinators, 
chairperson, and working groups. To specify in detail rules and guidelines for the power trade 
under the IGA, a regional power trade operating agreement (PTOA) in the GMS will be prepared 
with ADB assistance.4 The PTOA is a vital and integral component of the GMS flagship 
program, which was endorsed by the GMS summit meeting. The PTOA will provide harmonized 
rules of technical coordination and agree cross-border transmission tariff schemes, and will 
have  an  important  role  in  providing  the  policy  environment  needed  to  attract  physical 
investments from the private sector. 
 
7.  The master plan study recommended an indicative plan on power interconnections in the 
subregion, based on power demand forecast, generation and transmission system  planning 
scenarios, and its economic evaluation. The recommendations include (i) a 230 kilovolt (kV) line 
between Phnom Penh in Cambodia and Chau Doc in Viet Nam in 2004;5 (ii) 115 kV line 
between Thailand and western Cambodia in 2004; (iii) 500 kV line between Roi Et in Thailand 
and Ha Tinh in Viet Nam via the Lao PDR in 2009; (iv) 500 kV line between Savannakhet in the 
Lao PDR and Pleiku in Viet Nam in 2010; (v) 230 kV line between Nam Mo in the Lao PDR and 
Ban Mai in Viet Nam in 2009; (vi) 230 or 500 kV line between Na Bon in the Lao PDR and Udon 
Thai in Thailand in 2008; (vii) 500 kV line between Tasang in Myanmar and Mae Moh in 
Thailand  in  2012;  (viii) 500 kV line between Jinghong of Yunnan province of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) and Tha Wung in Thailand in 2013; (ix) 230 or 500 kV line between 
Malutang of Yunnan Province in the PRC and Soc Son in Viet Nam in 2019; and (x) 230 kV line 
between Sambor in Cambodia and Tan Dinh in Viet Nam in 2019.6 The proposed transmission 
line between Roi Et and  Ha Tinh will be the first power interconnection among the three 
countries in the GMS to link power networks of Thailand and Viet Nam. 
 
8.  The transfer of about 1,000 megawatts (MW) of electricity via a new double-circuit 500 
kV transmission line from the power plant of the proposed Nam Theun 2 hydropower project in 
the Lao PDR to Roi Et in Thailand has been under preparation by a private company, called 
Nam Theun 2 Power Company. The Nam Theun 2 Project is structured as a build-own-operate-
transfer, with a concession period of 25 years.  The concession agreement was signed in 
October 2002 by the Government of the Lao PDR and a developer. The power purchase 
agreement was formally signed on 8 November 2003 by the Electricity Generating Authority of 
Thailand, Electricité du Laos, and a developer. The construction of the new transmission line is 
scheduled to be completed in 2009/10. Taking into account available capacity of the planned

9.  Through the proposed interconnection, the first power exchange between Thailand and

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The purpose of the TA is to support GMS members’ strategy for promoting regional 
power exchange among members by assisting in the preparation of a feasibility study for the 
proposed 190 kilometers of the 500 kV power transmission line and ancillary facilities between 
the Lao PDR and Viet Nam, taking into account a planned 500 kV transmission line between 
Thailand and the Lao PDR so as to interconnect the grids of Thailand and Viet Nam, realize the 
benefits of power exchange, and extend economic cooperation among Lao PDR, Thailand, and 
Viet Nam. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will (i) estimate the quantity of power trade between Thailand and Viet Nam 
based on power demand and supply forecasts in each country, especially near project areas,9 
and the different peak loads in three countries; (ii) identify the best scheme for determining the 
transmission wheeling charge and its commercial arrangements, especially for Lao PDR’s 
investment modalities through distributional analysis of project costs and benefits in individual 
countries; (iii) make engineering study of options available for power exchange between Roi Et 
in Thailand and Ha Tinh in Viet Nam via the Lao PDR, including impact on the planned 
transmission line between Thailand and Lao PDR; (iv) study in detail the best option including 
cost estimates for transmission and ancillary facilities for the proposed project; (v) conduct 
economic  and  financial  evaluation  of  the  Project;  (vi) determine  appropriate  procurement 
packaging  and  procedures  to  facilitate  project  implementation;  (vii) determine  development 
impact on poverty; and (viii) assess social and environmental impacts (including adequate 
public consultations and disclosure), necessary mitigating measures, and management and 
monitoring programs. A summary of the initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 1. 
 
12.  To implement the TA efficiently, the consultants will first estimate the quantity of power 
trade between Thailand and Viet Nam; and identify the best scheme for determining the 
transmission wheeling charge and tariff, including options for Lao PDR’s investment modalities 
through distributional analysis of costs and benefits in individual countries. After the three 
countries reach consensus at the steering committee meeting (para. 14), other necessary tasks 
for the feasibility study will be undertaken.

C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of TA is estimated at $960,000 equivalent comprising $614,000 in foreign 
exchange and $346,000 in local currency equivalent. ADB will provide $800,000 equivalent to 
finance the entire foreign exchange cost and $186,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. 
The TA will be financed on a grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program. The Governments of 
Lao PDR, Thailand, and Viet Nam have agreed to provide on a pro rata basis $160,000 
equivalent in local currency, consisting of services to be provided (para. 14). Details of the cost 
estimates  and  financing  plan  for  the  TA  are  in  Appendix 2. The Governments have been 
advised that approval of the TA by ADB does not commit ADB to finance the ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The Executing Agency for the TA will be ADB and a steering committee will be its 
implementation agency. The steering committee comprising three representatives from each 
country  will  be  set  up  for  overall  coordination  among  relevant  ministries  and  agencies, 
consultants, and ADB, including extensive consultations with stakeholders and nongovernment 
organizations. Each government will appoint three representatives, including a coordinator, and 
will assist in preparing and collecting data, participate in the steering committee meeting, and 
help organize the meetings as necessary. To help the consultants carry out the feasibility 
studies in a timely manner, each government will make available a team of counterpart staff 
consisting of representatives from the ministries and utilities concerned and arrange for the 
concerned utility to provide office accommodation, local communication facilities, office support 
staff, and other administrative support including  arrangements for the consultant’s travel to 
project areas. Also, each government will undertake necessary consultations and workshops 
with  stakeholders,  project-affected  people,  and  civil  society  including  the  nongovernment 
organization, and relevant project documents will be put in a government’s web site in local 
languages. 
 
15.  The TA will require about 17 person-months of services by a team of international 
consultants and about 17 person-months10 from domestic consultants. The study will be carried 
out by a multidisciplinary team of experts with experience in economic and commercial aspects 
of  power  exchange  among  countries;  design,  construction,  and  operation  of  high-voltage 
transmission networks; development and poverty impact analysis; and environmental and social 
impact assessment of such projects. Domestic consultants will be hired to collect necessary 
power  sector  information  and  carry  out  detailed  social  and  environmental  surveys11 and 
consultations  for  the  Project.  The  consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of the Consultants  and other arrangements for engaging domestic 
consultants. Equipment to be financed under the TA will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement. The outline terms of reference for consultants that will be required 
are in Appendix 3. 
 
16.  The TA will start in January 2004 and will be completed by December 2005. Consulting 
services will begin in September 2004 and will be completed by August 2005. The consultants 
will submit (i) an inception report within 3 weeks of the start of the consulting services; (ii) an 
evaluation report estimating the quantity of power trade between Thailand and Viet Nam and

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
preparing the GMS Power Interconnection Project, Phase I, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty: 
 
The power sector is regarded as fundamental for poverty reduction and economic growth and development. 
Without adequate electricity, many development outcomes cannot be achieved. The ability of governments to fulfill 
economic development plans to support social development and off-farm job creation depends on power availability 
to support expansion of commercial and industrial activities. Electrification is regarded as so important for achieving 
other development goals that it constitutes a national goal on its own.  
 
Securing power supply, reducing tariffs, and increasing accessibility have significant direct and indirect 
impacts for end-consumers, especially the poor, who generally spend a larger share of their income on electricity 
consumption than non-poor consumers do. On the micro level lower electricity tariff reduces expenditures and brings 
about increased socioeconomic activity resulting from increased consumption. An increase in socioeconomic activity 
will contribute to economic growth and development.  
 
Bringing electricity to new communities and households will boost social and economic activity: improved 
ability to store vaccines, increased security, longer hours of social and economic activity, and longer hours for 
children to study at night. Electricity also brings about increased access to information and enjoyment, improving the 
quality of life in general.   
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis        Proposed Poverty Classification:  
Beneficiary nonspecific intervention 
Thematic Classification:  
Economic growth, regional cooperation   
     
 
Poverty analysis will comprise assessment of the impacts on existing consumers and new consumers. It will 
focus and on economic growth and development. It will pay particular emphasis on the ability of the poor to connect 
and benefit directly from electricity and on the affordability of up-front costs and tariffs. 
 
 The development impact study of the transmission project will make use of existing studies, surveys, and 
country-specific and regional poverty data; and will include a poverty profile of potential project beneficiaries from the 
regional and country perspectives. The assessment will be carried out on three levels: (i) direct, (ii) indirect, and (iii) 
macroeconomic. Mechanisms through which poverty and vulnerability of the near poor are reduced will be identified 
and subjected to qualitative and quantitative assessment. The type and extent of effects, and the mechanisms 
through which they take place, together with key assumptions and risks, will be summarized in a matrix to give an 
overview of the distributional impacts across key socioeconomic groups. 
  
Direct Impacts on Poverty  
 
The analysis will establish a poverty profile and examine the impacts of direct access to electricity and 
assess the affordability of up-front charges and tariffs in each country. The analysis will be based on rapid field 
assessment and existing surveys and studies.  
 
Indirect Impacts on Poverty 
 
The study will include a review of the impact on development aspects, interlinking the project effects of 
increased power supply with sectoral growth patterns and employment, on poverty in the identified target project 
areas at country and regional levels. It will use country-specific data, sectoral data, and socioeconomic surveys.  It 
will examine the impact potential for sectoral growth patterns, labor absorption of unskilled versus skilled labor, and 
implications for income and income source diversification for households across socioeconomic groups as a result of 
the power exchange.

Macroeconomic Impacts on Poverty 
 
The macroeconomic impact analysis will focus on the impact of the economic growth effect of the Project on 
the poor and the ability of the poor to benefit from economic growth.  
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Stakeholder analysis:  Identification of the socioeconomic profile of project beneficiaries, including ethnic minorities, 
through participatory field appraisal. 
 
A stakeholder analysis will be an integral part of resettlement planning. For transmission and distribution line routings, 
information  dissemination  to  and  consultations  with  people  and  local  communities  in  affected  areas  will  be 
undertaken. The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) will include a design for a full stakeholder participation 
strategy to be applied before and during the construction period. The strategy will include design of public information 
disclosure about the project scope, impacts, mitigating and enhancement measures, including compensation and 
resettlement options and grievance procedures.  Local authorities have committed to assign counterpart staff to work 
with the consultants during the TA. 
 
Participation strategy required: Yes – for resettlement planning, implementation, and monitoring.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consultants will prepare a feasibility study for the proposed 500 kilovolt (kV) power 
transmission line and ancillary facilities between the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao 
PDR) and Viet Nam so as to enable power exchange and trade among Lao PDR, Thailand, and 
Viet  Nam.  The  consultant  will  coordinate  the  work  closely  with  the  Electricity  Generating 
Authority of Thailand (EGAT), Electricite de Laos (EdL), Electricity of Vietnam (EVN), and Nam 
Theun 2 Power company to ensure that the proposed Project is compatible with each country’s 
technical specification and with Nam Theun 2 development project, with respect to power 
carrying  capacity,  power  system  configuration,  system  stability  and  fault  levels,  insulation 
coordination,  load  dispatching  and  communication  facilities,  operation  and  maintenance 
procedures, and safety aspect. Each consultant will prepare relevant sections of the report and 
recommendation of the President (RRP) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The terms of 
reference for the consultants will include, but will not necessarily be limited to, the following: 
 
1.  Economic Analysis (3 person-months; international) 
 
2.  In accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Economic Analysis of Projects, the consultants 
will undertake the following tasks, including preparation of relevant appendixes and sections of 
the RRP:  
 
(i)  Review  all  relevant  data  and  report  relating  to  the  regional  power  sector, 
including work in progress. Identify and address information gaps. Prepare up-
dated load forecasts for Lao PDR, Thailand, and Viet Nam to assess peak 
demand  and  supply,  especially  in  the  northeastern  region  of  Thailand  and 
northern region of Viet Nam; and subsequent benefits of power exchange among 
the three countries, considering a planned 500 kV transmission line between Lao 
PDR and Thailand as well as expected future development of independent power 
producers near the project area.  
 
(ii)  Review the expansion plan of each country to meet load forecast, including 
assumptions and constraints on which the plan is based. Identify and assess 
risks with the projections. Assess implications of various forecast scenarios. 
Conduct sensitivity analysis of load forecasts. 
 
(iii)  Identify  and  assess  least-cost  alternatives  for  addressing  domestic  power 
demand in each country. Prepare a least-cost justification matrix for the proposed 
Project  from  the  perspectives  of  Lao  PDR,  Thailand,  Viet  Nam,  and  the 
subregion.  Assess  risks  and  necessary  mitigating  measures  with  each 
alternative.  
 
(iv)  Propose a methodology for determining the tariff for wheeling power over the 
proposed  transmission  system,  and  determine  the  adequacy  of  that  tariff

(v)  Carry out in-depth economic analysis of the project for each individual country

(vi)  Identify stakeholders, including categories of end-consumers; and conduct a

  2.  Financial Analysis (3 person-months, international) 
 
3.  In accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of 
Investment  Projects  (2001),  the  consultant  will  undertake  the  following  tasks,  including 
preparation of relevant appendixes and sections of the RRP: 
 
(i)   Carry out in-depth financial analysis of the Project, including calculation of the 
financial rate of return and weighted average cost of capital, taking into account 
financial costs and benefits; conduct relevant sensitivity analysis of identified 
risks, including future restructuring plan of the power sector in each country.  
 
(ii)  Review the latest available audited and/or unaudited financial statements of EdL 
and  EVN  and  their  financial  management  capabilities,  and  make  any 
recommendations for improvements and institutional strengthening. 
 
(iii)  For the use of the planned transmission line between Lao PDR and Thailand, 
propose the appropriate schemes for calculating financial charges and determine 
the most likely financial charges, in consultation with the Nam Theun 2 Power 
Company and EGAT.  
 
(iv)  Recommend appropriate investment modalities (including but not limited to joint 
ventures,  build-own-operate-transfers,  and  other  forms  of  public-private 
partnerships) for the construction and operation of the Project to ensure the 
financial viability of investments. 
 
(v)  Propose  a  market-based  wheeling  charge  for  power  over  the  proposed 
transmission system, and review the adequacy of the tariffs compared with the 
financial costs and debt service requirements of the Lao PDR for the Project.  
 
(vi)   Prepare  a  financing  plan,  including  proposed  ADB  lending,  any  prospective 
cofinancing, and appropriate counterpart funds for local currency expenditures. 
 
3.  Engineering and Management Aspects (3 person-months, international) 
 
4.  The  consultant  will  undertake  the  following  tasks,  including  preparation  of  relevant 
appendixes and sections of the RRP:

Appendix 3  11 
 
(i)  Review  various  generation  and  long-term  transmission  expansion  plans, 
including the regional indicative master plan on power interconnection in the 
GMS and EVN’s study for power interconnection between Lao PDR and Viet 
Nam. 
 
(ii)  Determine the need of the proposed substation/switch station at Savannakhet 
and series compensation along the transmission line between Thailand and Viet 
Nam, and consult with Nam Theun 2 Power Company to utilize the planned 
transmission line between Thailand and Lao PDR, including design specification 
and available transmission capacity.  
 
(iii)  Carry out a detailed study of the best option including design of towers, choice of 
conductors, substation/switching station layout, equipment selection, insulation 
coordination, and design of communication system and load dispatching facilities 
as well as an optimal route for the transmission line to minimize social and 
environmental  impacts,  taking  into  account  expected  development  of 
independent power producers near project area. 
 
(iv)  Provide  technical,  economic,  and  financial  justification  of  the  Project  and 
compare it with available alternatives, taking into account the findings of 1, 2, 4, 
5, and 6 in the TOR. 
 
(v)  Prepare a detailed list of materials, facilities, equipment, and work and estimate 
their costs, separated into foreign and local components. 
 
(vi)  Outline project implementation and procurement arrangements including contract 
packaging, and prepare a project implementation schedule, taking into account 
the experience from EdL and EVN’s previous and ongoing transmission line 
projects and local ability to carry out the civil works. 
 
(vii)  Determine  an  adequate  project  management  organization  and  the  inputs  of 
expertise  and  person-months  for  preconstruction  activities  and  construction 
supervision;  prepare  terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services  for  project 
implementation and operation and maintenance of project facilities.  
 
(viii)  Identify necessary operation facilities and human resources to coordinate power 
trade, information exchange and technical dispute resolution among the three 
countries. 
 
(ix)  Assess the likely technical risks facing various aspects of the Project and carry 
out a sensitivity analysis to check the project viability under those risks. 
 
4.  Development and Poverty Impact Analysis (2 person-months, international) 
 
5.  The consultants will analyze the development impact of the Project and its impact on 
poverty reduction in accordance with ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis and will 
undertake the following tasks, including preparation of relevant appendixes and sections of the 
RRP  and  project  framework:  (i)  assess  the  likely  development  impact  on  economic 
activity/growth, sectoral distribution, employment and social activity for each individual country 
and on the subregion. Prepare a summary poverty/distributional impact matrix, describing the

12  Appendix 3 
channels through which direct, indirect, and macroeconomic development impacts may take 
place. Include identified risks and mitigating measures (as indicated in (iii)); (ii) prepare a 
socioeconomic and poverty profile of potential project beneficiaries in each country and in the 
subregion for the purpose of conducting a distributional analysis of net benefits; (iii) on the basis 
of field assessment of existing socioeconomic data and surveys, prepare a poverty impact 
analysis that clearly assesses the affordability of up-front costs, tariffs and other potential 
constraints/risks and impacts/benefits; and (iv) specify indicators to monitor the benefits on 
socioeconomic development and poverty: establish procedures and provide cost estimates for 
benefit monitoring and evaluation in terms of ADB’s  Guidelines for Benefit Monitoring and 
Evaluation. 
 
5.  Environmental  Aspects  (3  person-months,  international;  6  person-months, 
domestic) 
 
6.  In  accordance  with  the  relevant  ADB  guidelines  and  policies  for  environmental 
assessment, the consultant will undertake the following tasks, including preparation of relevant 
appendixes and sections of the RRP: (i) conduct an environmental impact assessment/initial 
environmental  examination  (EIA/IEE)  of  the  proposed  transmission  line,  substations,  and 
ancillary facilities, considering the likely impacts associated with construction activities, as well 
as the long-term impacts during operation; (ii) formulate appropriate environmental mitigating 
measures, monitoring program, and environmental management plan to address these impacts 
as part of the EIA/IEE and assess the environmental benefits of the proposed activities, and any 
capacity-building measures that may be needed; and (iii) prepare an EIA/IEE report and a 
summary EIA/IEE based on ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines, and any applicable 
procedures or guidelines for environmental assessment as required by the governments of Lao 
PDR and Viet Nam; include the costs of recommended mitigating and monitoring measures, 
and any capacity-building measures are in the proposed Project costs; and prepare the terms of 
reference for any further detailed environmental assessments, if required, in consultation with all 
stakeholder groups through the participatory framework. 
 
6.  Social Aspects (3 person-months, international; 6 person-months, domestic) 
 
7.  In accordance with relevant ADB policies, handbooks, and guidelines, the consultant will 
undertake the following tasks, including preparation of relevant appendixes and sections of the 
RRP: (i) identify and prepare socioeconomic profiles of the affected communities in the project 
areas  in  terms  of  household  sizes,  demographic  trends,  income  sources  and  levels, 
occupations, socioeconomic conditions, social service infrastructure, and social organizations, 
in accordance with (a) relevant ADB guidelines and publications, including the Handbook on 
Poverty and Social Analysis  (2001), Handbook on Resettlement (1998), and  Handbook for 
Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Projects (1994); and (b) the requirements of the Lao PDR 
and Viet Nam; the profiles will include gender and local ethnic minority profiles; carry out any 
further surveys as necessary; (ii) undertake social analysis as per the above guidelines and 
ADB's policies on involuntary resettlement (1995), indigenous peoples (1999), and gender and 
development (1998); identify the affected populations and principal beneficiaries of the Project; 
assess the stage of development of various groups of the population and characterize the 
special needs and demands of each group; (iii) evaluate the likely social impact of the Project 
and describe the social justification of the Project, particularly the potential for indigenous 
peoples or other vulnerable groups to be significantly and adversely affected; if the social 
analysis identifies the need to develop an ethnic minority development plan in accordance with 
the ADB’s policy on indigenous peoples, prepare (a) a plan that will be time-bound and costed 
and take into account the desires and preferred options of ethnic minorities, both women and

Appendix 3  13 
men, to be affected by the Project; (b) a study to identify potential adverse effects on ethnic 
minorities; (c) detailed design of measures to avoid, mitigate, or compensate for these adverse 
effects; (d) measures to ensure and strengthen the capacity of the social, legal, and technical 
skills of government institutions that are responsible for ethnic minorities’ affairs; (e) to involve 
appropriate institutions and nongovernment organizations with expertise in matters relating to 
ethnic minorities; (f) a design considers that local patterns of social organization, cultural beliefs, 
ancestral  territory,  and  resource  use  of  ethnic  minorities;  and  (g)  appropriate  budgetary 
resources for its implementation; describe the social justification of the proposed project; (iv) 
assess the impacts of land acquisition or loss of land use on affected people (loss of homes, 
agricultural and other lands; or loss of access to current income-generating activities), including 
impacts caused by permanent or temporary acquisition; if there are land acquisition impacts, 
prepare an implementable time-bound and costed resettlement plan as per ADB's Policy on 
Involuntary  Resettlement  and  Handbook  on  Resettlement,  involving  full  participation  of 
stakeholders and the implementing agency; base the plan on a population record1 and inventory 
of lost assets of all affected people and baseline socioeconomic and perception survey of at 
least 10% of marginally affected persons2 and 20% of severely affected persons,3 and a study 
to determine the replacement costs of all categories  of losses; prepare a detailed design of 
relocation and income restoring measures; prepare an entitlements matrix listing all likely effects 
of both permanent and temporary land acquisition; prepare mechanisms and documentation for 
disclosing information on compensation and resettlement options4 to affected persons prior to 
ADB’s management review meeting; assess the capacity of responsible institutions to plan, 
manage,  implement,  finance  and  monitor  effective  land  acquisition,  compensation,  and 
resettlement; and identify capacity-building measures to be included in the project; prepare a 
grievance  mechanism  and  appeal  procedures;  and  prepare  an  indicative  budget  for  land 
acquisition and resettlement costs with specific sourcing and approval process; (v) identify the 
potential risk of the spread of HIV/AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases during the 
construction  period,  and  prepare  a  detailed  plan  for  awareness  and  prevention  including 
resource implications; and (vi) hold at the initial stage of TA implementation one or more 
workshops  for  provincial  and  district  resettlement  committees  to  discuss  the  work  of  the 
consultants, coordination with Government agencies, and ADB requirements related to social 
safeguards. A final workshop will be held at the end of the TA to present findings relating to 
social safeguards, and the main contents of the resettlement plan, ethnic minority plan, and any 
other social safeguard documentation such as a gender strategy, if required, and plan for 
HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention during construction. 
                                                 
1 The population record or census is prepared through a count based on village or other local population data or 
census. 
2  The term affected person includes any person or persons, households, a firm, or private institution that, as of the 
cutoff date on account of such changes that result from the Project, or any of its components or part thereof, would 
have their (i) standard of living adversely affected; (ii) right, title, or interest in any house, land (including residential, 
commercial, agricultural, forest and grazing land), water resources, or any other movable or fixed assets acquired, 
possessed, restricted, or otherwise adversely affected, in full or in part, permanently or temporarily; or (iii) 
business, occupation, place of work or residence or habitat adversely affected, with or without displacement.  
3  The impact is severe if relocation is required or if 20% or more of productive assets are lost, such as 20% or more 
of total agricultural landholding. 
4  This may be in the form of a resettlement information brochure or leaflet, a summary resettlement plan, or a 
complete resettlement plan to be provided in an accessible place for affected persons in a language that they can 
understand.
